text: 1 which reads: "There is but one temple in the Universe and that is the human body. We touch heaven when we lay our hand on it. Thomas Carlyle, 1840"

2 EXT. PACIFIC COAST HIGHWAY вЂ” HIGH ANGLE вЂ” DAY 2 A God's-eye view of a long, winding stream of traffic, curling along the coastline, wrapping itself around the Santa Monica Mountains, flowing north to who can say wher Somewhere in the middle of it all, little more than a droplet in the stream, is a CADILLAC ALLANTE CONVERTIBLE with its top down.

3 I./E. CADILLAC ALLANTE вЂ” MOVING вЂ” DAY 3 As the California sun beats brilliantly down, as the rush of wind eddies and swirls inside the car, we take our pla directly behind the driver. From here, other than moment, we blown hair who she is there is little to be learned about the driver the obvious fact that she is a woman. For a see nothing of the world other than her windbillowing and and why we are traveling with her only deepens. Then, abruptly, VARIOUS CUTS of her hands on the wheel, o the speedometer, of her hand on the stickshift, etc. Occasionally, we sweep up to the mountains or down to the ocean or past the fence of some tony piece of real estate overlooking the water. But, always, we return to our poin of departure вЂ” behind the driver speeding up the Pacifi Coast Highway.
4  2. 5 EXT. COUNTRY ROAD вЂ” DAY 5 The Cadillac Allante rolls silently toward us before turning into a driveway that leads up the hill to a contemporary house.

6 EXT. CONTEMPORARY HOUSE вЂ” DAY 6 Pitched on a rolling hillside more evocative of Provence than Malibu is the dramatic, sharply angular two-story wi its eclectic exterior mix of corrugated walls and mirrore glass. As Allante approaches on the driveway, we begin to sense something slightly askew about this house and this place, and not all of it has to do with architecture.

7 EXT. ALLANTE вЂ” DAY 7 The driver's door opens and out swivels NINA: 38 years ol bright, attractive. But more than merely intelligent, she is shrewd; more than simply beautiful, she is alluring. And, perhaps, more to the point, she is shy about neither So one senses power as she rises out of the car, just as one senses insight as she takes a long, penetrating look around, just as one sees poise and grace as she glides toward the house.
8 NINA вЂ” MOVING 8 from the car ... up the walkway ... up to the front door with the mirrored glass. She slips her key into the lock without so much as a glance at her reflected image.

9 INT. CONTEMPORARY HOUSE вЂ” DAY 9 From the dramatic slope of the roof to the exposed rafter to the open, loft-like rooms seemingly suspended in space this house has been designed with an eclectic vengeance. Tasteful, mind you. But nonetheless a conspicuous scheme, a captivating diversion for the restless eye. (CONTINUED)

9 All this has long ago ceased to impress Nina, who immediately ducks inside the BEDROOM to her right and sli off her shoes before continuing barefoot down the HALLWAY The day's mail awaits her, stacked tidily on a chest midw down the hall. Taking the mail in hand, she begins sortin through it even as she ascends the short staircase to the MAIN ENTERTAINING AREA of the house. There she stands, in the middle of the floor, absorbed in some letter or other, when footsteps come quickly down a staircase and DEE DEE appears. Dee Dee, a very young, very eager, very uncertain 24-year Nina, who looks up coolly from her letter.

(painfully self-conscious, perhaps with a frantic glance at her watch) You're home? (suddenly talking to herself) Great, Dee'D. (just as suddenly talking to Nina again) I mean, there you are, standing right in front of me.
(doing nothing to put her at ease) Hello, Dee Dee.
Hi, Nina. A few tentative steps forward.
How was your day?
Very pleasant вЂ” in a grim sort of way. As Nina returns to her letter, Dee Dee moves quickly into the kitchen.
10 INT. KITCHEN вЂ” DAY 10 From a bucket of ice, Dee Dee removes a chilling bottle o white wine and pours a glass.
11 INT. ENTERTAINMENT AREA вЂ” DAY 11 Dee Dee now appears with a glass of wine, which Nina take from her. With the wine glass in one hand and her mail in the other, Nina sprawls leisurely on a sofa.
And how were things around here? But before Dee Dee can utter even syllable, Nina cuts her off.
Oh, did that what's-his-name, the strange bald lawyer call?
No.
How about Douglas вЂ” did he reconfirm for this afternoon?
No, no one called.

If he ever does call me here, it's fine to give the number for the car вЂ” the lawyer. He represents Merkey, the artist I'm showing next month. Douglas already has the number. Which must mean he's still coming вЂ” if he didn't call.
(not knowing if this requires a response) Well, yeah. Nina looks up: nothing like a response was either expecte or desired. (CONTINUED)
(back into the mail) So?
What...?
How were things around here? were about to say? You
The gardener came.
And how is Mr. Li?
He cleared out that underbrush, where you asked about.
Good.
Did the deep-root fertilization, too. Dee Dee hovers a little too near the sofa, prompting Nina to gaze up at her expectantly.

I paid all the bills, the checks are on your desk, you just have to sign them. And I bought some haddock from the fishman this morning, I made a curry sauce to go with it, all you have to do is pop it in the oven, I left the directions.
And you'd like to go home now. Dee Dee nods sheepishly.
Go. Dee Dee crosses slowly to the staircase.
Mr. Li said he won't be back again for three weeks. He has to go to (MORE) (CONTINUED)
DEE DEE (cont'd) Taiwan, I think he was trying to tell me. Some family thing.
No doubt.
He wanted to know if you wanted his nephew to come the next two weeks.
And you told him yes, I hope. Dee Dee nods.

You're a good little wife, Dee Dee. Every woman should have one. Taking this as a compliment, she smiles and disappears. After a moment, the front door opens and closes. After a moment more, Nina rises with wine glass in hand and goes the BACK DOOR. She gazes pensively through the glass, perhaps watching Dee Dee go, perhaps not.
12 which reads: "Preparation The goal of the massage is to relax all the senses. Prepare with this in mind."
13 INT. HOUSE вЂ” DAY 13 Nina slips a CD into the compact disc player, and we hear the first, deep, barely audible bars of Albinoni's Adagio in G-Minor. As the music continues ethereally UNDER, we:
14 INT. BEDROOM DRESSING CLOSET вЂ” DAY 14 Standing in front of a full-length mirror, Nina takes a moment to study herself in her suit, her uniform, if you will. (CONTINUED)

After a moment, after drinking off a little too much wine for one sip, she puts the glass to one side. Then, withou taking her eyes off herself, she begins removing her clothes. It is a slow and sultry dance, and her eyes, rapt hypnotically, never leave the mirror as she slides out of her skirt ... her blouse ... her nylons ... her bra.... Only gradually does it occur to us that there may be something other than prurience at stake here. This strip is not a tease but a conscious peeling away of layer upon layer of her well-ordered, well-practiced life. If she stares, it's only because she is making certain that absolutely nothing of her accustomed life is left. Once all her clothes are off, she takes another moment to study herself. Then, after retrieving a robe from an adjoining bathroom, she starts into the hallway.

15 EXT. HOUSE вЂ” JACUZZI вЂ” DAY 15 She tests the steaming, bubbling water with the graze of foot. Then, dropping her robe, she eases her body down, penetrating the water until she is submerged to the neck. Allowing her head to fall gently back, she gazes heavenwa at the starry night. She is drifting now; her mind is soaring across space and time.
16 INT. BATHROOM вЂ” DAY 16 Standing in the shower, allowing the water to cascade ove him, is a handsome, rugged man in his middle 20s, a man w will later come to know as DOUGLAS.
17 still in the jacuzzi, still gazing heavenward, still drifting.
18 EXT. STREET вЂ” IN FRONT OF THE CONTEMPORARY HOUSE вЂ” DA Turning into the driveway is a SMALL, UNASSUMING CAR вЂ” Yugo, perhaps вЂ” the sort of car that must have always (CONTINUED)
looked as rickety as it does now, even rolling off the assembly line.

19 EXT. JACUZZI вЂ” DAY 19 So far adrift is Nina that it takes her a moment to reali that the car is pulling up the driveway. But when she finally does see the car, she inches forward curiously. As she watches the car disappear around the front of the house, she reaches for her robe and climbs out of the jacuzzi.

20 EXT. DRIVEWAY вЂ” DAY 20 As he slides out from behind the wheel and unbends himsel onto the driveway, we get our first clear look at FITCH. At 44, he seems to be in equal parts showing his age and hiding it. Yes, his face is deeply lined. Yes, he is as grey as he is not. Yet, at the same time, he is as lean and agile as he was 20 years earlier. With hair that seems a day or two shy of its next trim an clothing that is вЂ” in a word вЂ” utilitarian, he resemb nothing so much as the publisher of a natural foods catalogue. From his place by the car, he eyes the house for a moment Then, pushing forward the driver's seat, he leans in and dislodges a long, rectangular object (his unassembled, portable massage table) that is wedged diagonally across the interior of the car. Along with the massage table, he pulls out what used to b known as a "gym bag." He then glances at his watch, locks the driver's door, and with massage table and bag in hand circles around to the sidewalk leading up to the house.
21 INT. HOUSE вЂ” DAY 21 Nina moves quickly down the HALLWAY, tying her robe as sh goes. When she reaches the end, she ducks into the BEDROO and goes to a window for a better look.
25 26 EXT. HOUSE вЂ” WALKWAY вЂ” DAY 26 Fitch walks deliberately toward the house, his eyes surveying the exterior, the corrugated walls, the impenetrable mirrored-glass windows.
27 FITCH вЂ” MOVING 27 toward ANOTHER HOUSE: small, rural, eerily still, the perfect setting for вЂ” well, who can say just what?

28 EXT. HOUSE вЂ” AS BEFORE вЂ” DAY 28 When Fitch reaches the front steps, he removes a business card (not his own) and matches the hand-written name scrawled on the back of it with the name by the door. He takes another look at his watch then presses a button on the intercom.
29 INT. HOUSE вЂ” HOME ENTERTAINMENT CENTER вЂ” DAY 29 With the push of a button, Albinoni falls silent.
30 INT. HOUSE вЂ” FRONT DOOR вЂ” DAY Nina opens the blinds and peers curiously. was expecting, Fitch is obviously not he. 30 Whomever she

31 EXT. FRONT DOOR вЂ” DAY 31 Fitch stands in front of the mirror-glass, seeing absolutely nothing of Nina, glancing inadvertently at his reflected image, perhaps adjusting his hair slightly when he does.
32 INT. FRONT DOOR вЂ” DAY 32 She peers at him a moment longer, then:
Can I help you?
(through the door) Hi. She opens the door.
(eyeing him with suspicion) Yes? I'm Fitch.
Fitch.
Fitch?
I'm here for your appointment. As if to introduce some physical evidence in his defense, he points to the portable massage table at his side.
Where's Douglas?
Didn't he call you? He said he was вЂ” he would вЂ” call you. He didn't call you.
To tell me what?
That he couldn't make it.
Douglas?
He said. It's difficult to tell which has Nina puzzled more: Fitch presence or his appearance. Whoever the much talked about (CONTINUED)

Douglas is, he definitely doesn't wear Birkenstock sandal With sox. Nina then takes an absent-minded step back, giving the impression вЂ” more or less unintended вЂ” that she would Fitch to come right in. Without giving it a second thought, he squeezes by her in the house. And so he's well inside before she even realizes what has happened.
So where would you like me to set up, Nina? Without waiting for a response, Fitch starts for the adjoining bedroom, but Nina intercepts him.
We're usually this way. She extends a hand, indicating the end of the hallway is their intended direction of travel. With a bemused shake of the head, Nina closes the front door and follows.
33 34 INT. HALLWAY вЂ” DAY 34 As she closes the door, Fitch confidently walks to the en of the hallway and turns into the large, open studio. Seeing him disappear, she takes off after him.

35 36 INT. STUDIO вЂ” DAY 36 Fitch is already in the middle of the room by the time Ni appears in the doorway. He puts his massage items to one side and begins to wander curiously through the room, examining things that he comes across.
Where is he, do you know?
Who? (CONTINUED)
Douglas.
Didn't come up. He picks up a book that he finds lying on a table. crosses to him and takes it from him. She
"The Sun Also Rises."
I liked it. A brief beat, then:
You see, I'm really very ... accustomed to him вЂ” Douglas. Fitch nods a small, noncommittal nod.
I like him.... Fitch nods again.
I really like him.... Fitch nods yet again.
And it takes time вЂ” for a woman, at least вЂ” it takes time getting comfortable, really comfortable with a man who's ... She doesnвЂ™t finish her thought.
Doug's got the touch. He pulls open a sliding glass door that leads out to the deck. He steps outside. After a moment, she follows.
37 as Fitch appears at her side. (CONTINUED)
But without even picking up the phone or ...? Fitch peers at her, having temporarily lost the train of thought.
Douglas. When you have a relationship with someone вЂ” a business relationship вЂ” we go back, he and I вЂ” you expect some consideration.
He seemed to be in a rush. young. He's very
He's not so terribly young.
No, not so. But he is young. A lot younger than he thinks he is, anyway. Besides, he could have not called either one of us. A beat, as he walks farther onto the deck, drinking in th surroundings.
He's very talented.
He is. Good-looking kid, too. Women seem to go for him. A lot of his clients are women. Most, really. At this, she says nothing.
Outside's nice. Especially if you have some privacy. And you have some privacy.
Douglas does me outside.
A little cold tonight.
Where would you suggest then? (CONTINUED)
Some dark and quiet place. She nods her head.
You know, I was in such a hurry getting over here. I've got my oils and things, but sheets and towels ... She nods then they steps back into the house.
I left some stuff in the car.
38 INT. HOUSE вЂ” UPSTAIRS вЂ” DAY 38 Nina opens a linen closet, removes the sheets and towels that Fitch has asked for, then closes the closet door.
39 EXT. FITCH'S CAR вЂ” DAY 39 He removes another small bag or two from the car then closes the trunk.
40 INT. STUDIO вЂ” DAY 40 When Nina comes back, however, Fitch is nowhere to be see

41 INT. HOUSE вЂ” HALLWAY вЂ” DAY 41 Walking out of the studio, she sees the massage table jus where he left it: still leaning against a wall, still not set up. Now, a little curious вЂ” perhaps even a little concerned she starts out of the room in search of Fitch.
42 NINA вЂ” MOVING 42 through the house, picking up speed, until she at last walks into a bedroom where she discovers Fitch, examining some jewelry that is scattered across the top of a dresse
43 as Fitch turns to see Nina, eyes locked on him, coming closer. Without the slightest hesitation, he resumes studying the diamond bracelet that he spreads across his palm.
I'm fascinated with things. That is, I'm fascinated with the fascination with things.
This is my bedroom.
I thought it might be. My mother had a spectacular jewelry collection, as I recall. A dubious beat, as she wonders just what he may be up to.
(sensing her distrust) I wanted to wash up. And when I happened to walk by ... She hands over the sheets and towels, which forces him to hand over the bracelet.
Well, I wanted to wash up. She leads him into the bathroom, which we recognize as th one that Doug was showering in earlier.
44 which reads: (CONTINUED)
"The Massage Table The table should be tall enough to elevate the subject to a comfortable height."

45 INT. HOUSE вЂ” STUDIO вЂ” DAY 45 From a chair, Nina looks on as Fitch goes about the ritua of setting up his massage table. And it is just that: a ritual. Each piece, each bolt, each nut and washer, he assembles with devotion and ceremony, all of it perhaps a unconscious as not.
What massage is about in the end is healing. There are ways people can heal without drugs or words or prayers. That's it; that's the essence.
I never really gave it much thought.
Healing?
Massage вЂ” in those terms. I try not to intellectualize things too much. It makes life so grey. I'm more ... intuitive, I think. She watches as Fitch again immerses himself in his ritual then:
How old are you?
(smiling) Why do you ask?
I don't know, why not ask? I mean, you never learn anything without asking, do you?
(still smiling) Older than you. (CONTINUED)
She is now staring at him, as we:
46 where a BEARDED MAN, approximately Fitch's age, assembles an easel with the same sense of ritual and attention. The man looks up when we hear:
(v.o.) The laying on of hands вЂ” there's power in it.
47 THE SUN ROOM вЂ” AS BEFORE 47 Fitch looks up briefly from his work, seeing her staring him. But, clearly, he doesn't give it a second thought as he once more focuses his attention on the table.

But, in our culture, there are so many Western prejudices about illness and healing. We're really pretty tight-assed, medically speaking. Just think about it: when was the last time your doctor actually touched you? not probed or examined but touched you?
If it never happened, it was too recent. I don't like doctors вЂ” mine or anyone else's.
Because they consult with you, they talk with you over the phone, they prescribe drugs for you. But they don't actually вЂ” personally вЂ” heal you. They leave that up to time or chemistry.
I don't like doctors because ... I don't like doctors. A beat, then: (CONTINUED)
You've known Doug for how long? Fitch shrugs: Doug is a topic of conversation that he can either take or leave. And right now he feels more like leaving it than taking it.
Long enough to like him?
How long's that? (beat) It goes back to the ancients, you know.
What's that?

Massage. Maybe even earlier, some historians think. The Greeks were into massage mainly as a treatment, a healing art. They've got records of people like Socrates and Plato being massaged daily. And Plato lived to be 104.
Socrates did not.

(undeterred) But the Romans being who they were вЂ” essentially Italians without the loafers вЂ” they were the first to come up with the idea of massage as a form of foreplay. Courtesans got pretty handy at it. It was part of the transaction, finally.
Well, it's not like you have to have a degree in molecular biology to see a connection. Massage is sexual. Very sexual.
It can be. It doesn't have to be. It shouldn't always be. (CONTINUED)

I wasn't talking about sweating, screaming, orgasmic epiphany. It's just that you're lying there naked, someone's touching you in places you sure wouldn't let your father touch you, and it's ... arousing.

It's a form of communication. You just have to make sure you're both speaking the same language. Fitch makes a few final adjustments to the table. Seeing that he is nearly finished, Nina she sheds her rob It takes a moment for her to locate a towel, during which time Fitch gets an eyeful. He says nothing. She says nothing. But neither her complete lack of embarrassment nor his utter professional disinterest strikes us as entirely authentic. Finally spotting her towel, she draws it carelessly around hersel Fitch stands up.
Looks like we're ready to start.
We've already started.
What do you mean? Fitch reaches for his massage "tool bag" and begins removing items.

Well, most of any massage worth having takes place in your head. And I'm sure you've been preparing вЂ” (suddenly, a thought occurs to him) Why, are you in a hurry? Before she can reply, he pulls an extremely odd and not easily explained item out of his bag of tricks. He holds it up for her to see.
Funny thing, hunh? (CONTINUED)
He puts that item back and pulls out one or two more.
You might want to have some music. What was that music you were playing? before you turned it off?
I'll find something. She crosses out of the room. her. After a moment, he follows

48 From the doorway, Fitch watches as she climbs the stairs and goes to the stereo system. It's only when she makes her music selection and turns back that she sees him looking at her. A puzzling, slightly unsettling beat, then:
I'd say we're ready.
49 which reads: "The Back The back is the best place to begin any full body massage."
51 Nina now lies prone on the table. Fitch is, from all appearances, ready to go to work. He peels back the towel so that it doesn't quite cover her butt.
So what are we working on, Nina? (CONTINUED)
Any complaints? maladies? any part of your body that needs special attention?

The part that begins at my hair and ends at my toes. From his bag, he removes an impressive assortment of bottles and jars. He selects one then begins applying oil in long, slow, sweeping strokes until the whole of her ba is slick and glistening.

52 A SERIES OF SHOTS вЂ” THE ART OF THE MASSEUR 52 Hands float ... fingers unfold ... forearms bunch ... biceps flex ... shoulders tauten ... as IN and OUT OF FRA his body glides with power and grace. Watching, we are witness to nothing short of Fitch's complete mastery of his art: he is nothing short of the Baryshnikov of massage.

53 Younger. Slightly more muscular. Noticeably less accomplished. Decidedly less poetic. More ballroom than ballet. More James T. Farrell than Marcel Proust. And when the CAMERA moves slowly BACK, we see that it is not Fitch massaging Nina but the handsome, rugged man: Douglas. Every now and then, she lets out a small, involuntary sig which after a time begins to sound very much like a moan. This goes on for a moment or two, growing in intensity, until the spell is broken by:
(o.s.) It's my job, you know....
54 Fitch continues with warm, luxurious, circulating strokes beginning at the small of her back and flowing up to her shoulder blades.
You were going to say something about how tense I am.... Maybe he was. More likely he was undergoing some out-ofbo of her back that he massages.

Douglas always does. He's always telling me how much tension I have. Especially in my upper back, my shoulders. It's all because of my work.... A beat of expectation, as she waits for him to question h about her work. Then, when he does not, when he simply continues massaging her in intense silence, she answers anyway:

I own a gallery. A couple of them, actually. One here in town, off Melrose. Another in New York, Tribeca. And when it's your business, your baby вЂ” well, you know what they say about responsibility falling on your shoulders. It does вЂ” literally. A beat, then:
It's best not to talk so much.
Was I? talking too much?

Well, it's your massage. You can do anything you'd like. But you really should take some time to relax. I mean, you can't keep going all the time. Or is that what the people you work with do? (CONTINUED)

The people I work with limit their relaxation to what they can purchase in a vial. After he performs a series of long, deep strokes, she visibly loosens up. She seems to be taking his advice. Half-joking, he lifts one of her feet and lets it drop to the table.
Working already, see?

55 where the bearded man paints at an easel. The painting that he labors at is perhaps more naturalistic than what fashionable these days. The work is nevertheless accomplished. Just then, Nina drives by in her CAR. For some reason, th sight of the man at his easel captures her imagination. She makes a u-turn and drives back. After a moment, she is out of the car and over his shoulder. He turns, surprised to see anyone anywhere near him. She continues studying the painting, even as he studies her.
(as he continues painting) So what do you think of it? Nina gives an approving nod of the head.
56 After a brief, contempative beat вЂ”
How long have you been doing massage, Fitch?
Almost 20 years вЂ” off and on.
Interesting work. I'm sure you meet all kinds of people. Gives you a lot (MORE) (CONTINUED)
NINA (cont'd) of freedom, too, I bet. I mean, it's so portable: have table, will travel.... A brief beat, then:
I travel a lot вЂ” in my work. Too much, I'm starting to think. I guess it just depends how badly you want what you want... Another brief beat, then:
Do you like art? You seem like the sort of person who does.
And what sort of person is that?
Well, an ... (catching herself) What do you mean?
(more musing than argumentative) Just that I never thought there was a type, that's all. But I suppose you'd know more about that than I would.
Well, do you? enjoy art?
(after a moment of consideration) Who do you consider to be the great artists of this century?
How do you mean?
I mean who are the five greatest вЂ” or four вЂ” or three?
I'm really not in that business. (CONTINUED)
Would you say Picasso? Would he be one? Or maybe Chagall вЂ” ?
- I don't think you can quantify artistic achievement FITCH - or would you say Braque? or Klee?

What's your point, Fitch? Instead of replying, Fitch retreats for a moment, again massaging her in silence. His strokes now become a tease although from all appearances an inadvertent one вЂ” as h hands move nearer and nearer her ass. Finally, in a series of deep, slow strokes, he slips his hands under the towel and withdraws them, then slips them under again вЂ” to which she visibly succumbs. Her eyelid close heavily.
57 now in Fitch's place, leaning over the massage table, as his movements more or less echo the strokes that Fitch ha just performed.
58 on the table as she sighs deeply.
59 Nina emerges slowly from her reverie.
What was it you were going to say? No response.
You were going to say something and then you just stopped. (CONTINUED)
When there is still no response, she looks up to see that Fitch is gone. Then, as she slides off the table to go in search of him, she hears a strange CLICKING sound coming from the hallway.

60 INT. HALLWAY вЂ” DAY 60 Returning from his car, Fitch is clicking together TWO LARGE MAGNETS as he walks down the hall. Suddenly, a painting hanging on the wall catches his eye. It's about then that Nina emerges from the studio.

This is just me now, this is just my opinion. But so much of what passes for art today вЂ” contemporary art вЂ” is without any kind of reference point: moral, historic, nothing. It's not about anything.
Oh, I disagree. Modern art is critical. That's what makes it modern.
61 The bearded painter sits at the easel preparing his palet as Nina continues to linger over his shoulder.
Where do you show? The painter laughs.
62 INT. HALLWAY вЂ” AS BEFORE 62 Nina sees the magnets.
What are those?
(deadpan) I don't know. I just found them in the trunk of my car. (CONTINUED)
She looks askance at him: she takes him at his word.
They're magnets.
Magnets?
About 400 gauss potency вЂ” perfect for those hard-to-treat areas. Without pausing to explain further, he moves into the kitchen.
63 Nina follows Fitch in as he crosses to the stove. There, he turns on a burner and begins warming the magnets. Then, as she looks on with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension вЂ”
You really must visit my gallery. We've got a very interesting installation coming up next month I think you should see.
And what's that?
A history of women's fashion as a form of bondage. Fitch cocks an amused eyebrow.
Come and see it. I think you'll enjoy it. It has a certain point of view. It's funny. Ironic. Satiric.
A point of view.
Exactly. (CONTINUED)
I'll tell you вЂ” and this is why so much of art today is so pointless, I think вЂ” what we suffer from, our society, is a kind of bankruptcy of spirit.
I'm sure people have said something like as long as there have been people to say it.
Except this time it's true.
I'm sure they said that, too.
64 ALICE вЂ” CLOSE UP 64 20ish, stunning, she stares into the CAMERA, revealing le than she shows.
(v.o.) If you're talking about today вЂ” the way we live вЂ” it's fear вЂ” that's what defines us.
65 Fitch and Nina return: he with the magnets in hand, she a few steps behind him. Taking note the massage chair by th window, he crosses to it.
Is this yours? She nods. He indicates that she should sit in it, which she does. He then kneels before her, placing a warmed magnet beneath either of her feet.
Fear of change. Fear of the future. Technology transforming things faster than people can take in. It turns us into strangers, everyone. That's why people create the art they create. (CONTINUED)
Bad faith.
What is?
Blaming someone else вЂ” something else вЂ” technology вЂ” as if we had no responsibility for ourselves, our actions.
So what would you suggest?
I suggest we look inward, all of us, for starters. And then, I suggest we look outward.
And then do we all sit cross-legged on the floor, humming like gnats?
We might. We could. Why not? Or else we could just go out and kill all the gallery owners. A beat, as Nina, amused, smiles to herself.
66 which reads: "The Neck and Shoulders Neck tension is often the root of psychological fatigue."
67 Fitch now glides his hands along her spine up to her neck and shoulders. He begins to apply acupressure in a series of short, powerful bursts. (CONTINUED)
The power of his fingertips causes her to exhale audibly she tries to diffuse the discomfort through her breathing Hearing this, he doesn't stop. Nor does she ask him to.

68 where Douglas has once more replaced Fitch. The discomfor that he causes, however, plainly borders on pain, resembling nothing so much as controlled violence. Yet, the harder he massages her, the more she grunts and groans and gasps for breath and вЂ” from all indications just generally enjoys herself.
69 Although Fitch continues his acupressure strong and hard, the mood вЂ” in contrast to Nina and Douglas вЂ” seems downright pacific.
